Title: A winter storm wraps up in the South, with travel delays and power outages persisting
Description: The significant winter storm had passed in the South by Saturday morning, but travel issues and power outages were still ongoing. (Image credit: Megan Varner)

Title: How Jimmy Carter's love of music helped launch his presidential campaign
Description: Former President Jimmy Carter's close friends included the likes of Bob Dylan, Willie Nelson and the Allman brothers. (Image credit: Tom Hill)

Title: Why are so many indigenous Panamanians contracting HIV — and dying of AIDS?
Description: The government provides HIV medicines free of charge. Yet in one indigenous territory, cases and deaths are increasing at an alarming rate. (Image credit: Adam Williams for NPR)

Title: In a bitter fight for the Minnesota Legislature, Democrats have threatened a walkout
Description: A series of unexpected events after the narrow election has set up a power struggle in the Minnesota Legislature. Days before the legislative session kicks off, it's unclear who will take control. (Image credit: Clay Masters)

Title: Photos: Southern California residents return to devastation as two major wildfires rage on
Description: More than 100,000 Los Angeles County residents remain under evacuation orders, and the threat of fire there is not over. New evacuations were ordered last night and strong Santa Ana winds are expected to pick up again today. (Image credit: Mario Tama)

Title: LA fires rage on as those returning home try to ward off looters
Description: Firefighters continue to struggle against the wildfires around Los Angeles. The death count has risen and looting has become a problem amid the destruction.

Title: A family that fled the wildfires engulfing their Altadena home shares their experience
Description: The Wilson family evacuated from their home in Altadena, California before it burned down. NPR's Scott Simon speaks to Virginia Wilson and her 16-year old daughter, Charlotte.

Title: Bomb threats shadowed international reporters who covered Chinese celebrity dissident
Description: Reporters covering a Chinese dissident in Europe were accused of making bomb threats. An NPR investigation now has them wondering if it was the work of the Chinese government or someone else. (Image credit: AP)

Title: He brought us back alive': A former hostage remembers Jimmy Carter
Description: Former diplomat Barry Rosen was a hostage during the Iran crisis. In an interview with All Things Considered, he reflects on former President Jimmy Carter's quest to free him. (Image credit: JOE KLAMAR/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: An army of community volunteers springs into action as LA fires rage
Description: It's wild. There's people out here that have just created a chain,' said one woman who showed up to volunteer at a YMCA in Los Angeles' Koreatown neighborhood. (Image credit: Elise Hu)

Title: Amid the fires, LA is warning some residents the tap water isn't safe. Here's why
Description: Wildfires have a history of causing problems with the drinking water systems. In some affected areas around LA, officials are warning residents not to drink from the tap or even to shower. (Image credit: brazzo/iStockphoto)

Title: Is Trump's rhetoric on Greenland, Canada and Panama Canal a 'Madman Strategy'?
Description: The president-elect's undiplomatic talk in recent days of reclaiming the Panama Canal — and annexing Greenland and even Canada — have some experts comparing his strategy to Nixon's 'Madman Theory.' (Image credit: Emil Stach)

Title: A look at how one family keeps traditions alive at a rodeo extravaganza in Colorado
Description: The 30th anniversary of the Mexican Rodeo Extravaganza at the National Western Stock Show is a celebration of pageantry and cultural heritage. (Image credit: Amanda Lopez for NPR)

Title: Fox News headed for trial, again, over 2020 election fraud claims
Description: The defamation case brought by voting technology company Smartmatic against Fox News can proceed, a New York state appellate court rules. (Image credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images)

Title: More than half a million students were out of school because of LA fires this week
Description: School districts in and around Los Angeles shut down because of the fires. That includes LAUSD, the second largest school district in the country. (Image credit: Jireh Deng for NPR)

Title: A small seafood restaurant turns into a national donation hub for LA fire victims
Description: In response to the devastating fires raging in LA, a small restaurant in Surf City USA has become a channel for big help — from locals to people across the country — to support their neighbors up north. (Image credit: Emma Bowman/NPR)

Title: New photos show the volcanic plains of Mercury after a spacecraft fly-by
Description: The BepiColombo spacecraft flew less than 200 miles from Mercury's surface and photographed volcanic plains and icy craters.

Title: We Call Ourselves the Combat Witches.'
Description: Women from a Kyiv suburb create an all-female volunteer air defense unit. They say it's helped them deal with the trauma of a 2022 massacre by Russian troops.

Title: Venezuela's Maduro begins new term as US raise bounty for his arrest
Description: The US announces an increased $25 million reward for information leading to the arrest of Venezuelas President Maduro, on day he's sworn in for a third term. (Image credit: Matias Delacroix)

Title: Is smoke in your home? Here's how to make an air purifier from a box fan
Description: A large area of greater Los Angeles had unhealthy air Friday, due to particulate matter from large wildfires. Here are tips for breathing cleaner air indoors if its smoky outside. (Image credit: Mario Tama)

Title: Most Syrian refugees in Turkey are watching the new leadership before returning home
Description: Hundreds of Syrian refugees in Turkey are making a return to Syria every day, according to the Turkish Interior Ministry. But the majority are waiting to see how the new leadership takes shape.

Title: Why right-wing influencers are blaming the California wildfires on diversity efforts
Description: Prominent right-wing influencers are claiming that the response to the Los Angeles wildfires was hampered by workplace diversity policies. It's part of a wider strategy to discredit those policies. (Image credit: DAVID PASHAEE/Middle East Images/AFP via Getty)

Title: Biden extends protections for immigrants from Venezuela, El Salvador and Ukraine
Description: Close to a million migrants will be shielded from deportation for up to 18 months. (Image credit: Ben Curtis)

Title: Biden extends temporary protection for migrants of Venezuela, El Salvador, Ukraine
Description: People from Venezuela, El Salvador and Honduras has had Temporary Protected Status, TPS, for the longest time. With the Trump administration promising to end TPS, Central Americans are bracing for the possibility of being deported.

Title: U.S. ambassador to Israel makes his final push for release of U.S. hostages from Gaza
Description: We are going to do everything we can in this round to get all the American hostages, living and dead, out,' Ambassador Jacob J. Lew tells NPR. His tenure as President Biden's envoy ends this month. (Image credit: Maya Levin for NPR)

Title: U.S. ambassador to Israel talks about diplomatic efforts in the Israel-Hamas conflict
Description: As the U.S. ambassador to Israel, Jack Lew, prepares to leave his post, he talks about his diplomatic efforts to shape the direction of the Israel-Hamas war.

Title: One Ukrainian unit defends Kherson with Soviet-era weapons and the cover of darkness
Description: NPR's Brian Mann spends time with a Ukrainian mobile artillery unit as they prep their Soviet-era mobile cannon for a nighttime attack. Their goal? Stop Russia from crossing the Dnipro River and taking Kherson.

Title: The prison population is going up as prisons struggle with staffing and overpopulation
Description: The prison population has been creeping back upward. New laws in some states instituting harsher punishments threaten to further fill prisons, many of which are already understaffed and overcrowded.

Title: Cancelled flights, stranded cars, no power: Winter storm slams swath of U.S.
Description: Atlanta has seen nearly 1,000 flights grounded, while more than 34,000 Arkansans have lost power. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: What is the flame retardant that planes are dropping on the LA fires?
Description: As fire crews and air tankers work to block the wildfires' explosive growth, images of red clouds of fire retardant falling onto trees are common. What is it — and what's in it? (Image credit: David Swanson)

Title: Wildfire victims report looting. And, Trump set for sentencing in hush money case
Description: Southern California wildfire victims report looting after returning home to assess damages. And, President-elect Donald Trump is set for sentencing in a hush money conviction today. (Image credit: Ethan Swope)

Title: Inmates are fighting California wildfires in long-running and controversial practice
Description: California has turned to incarcerated firefighters since 1915. To those opposed to the use of inmates as firefighters, the system is seen as exploitative. (Image credit: Jae C. Hong)

Title: Firefighters battling LA fires make some progress, but harsh winds threaten gains
Description: Despite some progress, the biggest blazes — the Palisades and Eaton fires — rage uncontrolled as anxious residents receive alerts sent in error and face massive damages. (Image credit: Josh Edelson)

Title: How these suburban moms in Ukraine manage grief by training to down Russian drones
Description: Women from a Kyiv suburb traumatized by a 2022 massacre by Russian troops joined a volunteer air defense unit to take down Russia's drones — and deal with their fears. (Image credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for NPR)

Title: Who's in, who's out and who wants to rename the Gulf of Mexico? The quiz is back!
Description: This week, we tackle the Golden Globes, free speech, Girl Scout cookies, dragons and more. Add a perfect score to your New Year's resolutions! (Image credit: Amy Sussman/Getty Images, Harry How/Getty Images, Amy Sussman/Getty Images)

Title: Trump set for sentencing in his New York felony conviction
Description: Trump on Thursday exhausted his last legal maneuver to stop the sentencing, after a narrow majority of Supreme Court justices declined to intervene. (Image credit: Rebecca Noble)

Title: Q&A: CIA Chief on how the U.S. intel community handled Russia, China and Mideast
Description: In an exit interview with NPR's Mary Louise Kelly, CIA Director William Burns says he still thinks 'there's a chance' for a ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas war. (Image credit: Dee Dwyer for NPR)

Title: Her family thought they would return home the next day. Now, their house is gone
Description: Jinghuan Liu Tervalon packed a few documents, keepsakes and clothing before leaving her Altadena, Calif., home ahead of the fast-moving Eaton Canyon Fire. Her son returned to find rubble and ash. (Image credit: Jervey Tervalon)

Title: Transcript: NPR's full conversation with CIA Director William Burns
Description: In a wide-ranging exit interview, NPR's Mary Louise Kelly asks Central Intelligence Agency director William Burns about the resurgence of ISIS, and what's next for the intel community. (Image credit: Ian Morton)

Title: Trump set for sentencing Friday in his New York felony conviction
Description: Trump on Thursday exhausted his last legal maneuver to stop the sentencing, after a narrow majority of Supreme Court justices declined to intervene.

Title: How the deadly LA wildfires have harmed schools and families who rely on them
Description: NPR's A Martinez asks Los Angeles School Board member Nick Melvoin <> how deadly fires have harmed schools and the students and families who rely on them.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: An update on the latest news on the LA area wildfires, Trump set for sentencing in his New York felony conviction, TikTok lawyers to argue before the Supreme Court today against upcoming U.S. ban.

Title: Elon Musk's latest foray into politics: a live chat with Germany's far-right candidate
Description: With Germany's election in six weeks, Elon Musk was full of praise for his livestream guest on X: Alice Weidel, the far-right Alternative for Germany party's candidate for chancellor. (Image credit: Kay Nietfeld)

Title: Elon Musk meddles in German elections, again
Description: As the German election campaign gets underway, Elon Musk's endorsement of the far-right Alternative for Germany party has prompted outrage from the political centre. But with the AfD polling in second place and the Tesla tycoon set to host the party's chancellor candidate Alice Weidel at a talk on X, the other parties are struggling to find effective campaign strategies of their own.

Title: Meta built a global fact-checking operation. Will it survive?
Description: The company's policy reversal comes as the U.S. is diverging sharply from other countries over regulating social media. (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: Groups of Latino immigrants help to put out wildfires in Los Angeles area
Description: Many Latino immigrants in Los Angeles worked to extinguish some of the fires with hoses. They aren't firefighters, they were just helping people in other neighborhoods.

Title: NPR visits Qardaha, hometown of ousted Syrian President Assad
Description: We visit the hometown of the ousted Syrian President, Bashir al-Assad. Qardaha lies in northwest Syria, considered the heartlands of the Alawite religious sect.

Title: The way we track who owns a property or holds its title gives an opening to scammers
Description: When buying and selling homes, there is no national record of who owns a property, who has a title to it. The Planet Money team has the story of a new kind of villain trying to exploit that system.

Title: Hear the latest updates on the wildfires buring out of control in the LA area
Description: Several large wildfires continue to rage out of control in Los Angeles County. At least 10 people have been killed, according to the LA County Medical Examiner, and thousands have fled their homes.

Title: Venezuela's Maduro to be sworn in for third term as protesters take to the streets
Description: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro prepares to be sworn in for a third term despite accusations of stealing the last election. Thousands took to the streets to demand a return to democracy.

Title: A neighbors' bond that transcends age
Description: Two women, who differ in age by nearly 50 years, talk about their friendship. They were neighbors before they met, and when they finally did, they discovered a connection across the age gap.

Title: Jan. 6 Committee lead investigator Tim Heaphy discusses his insights in new book
Description: Tim Heaphy was the lead investigator for the House Jan. 6 committee. He also looked into the violence in Charlottesville in 2017. He's got a new book out with insights into that experience.

Title: Altadena residents return to neighborhood ravaged by the Eaton Fire
Description: LA area residents are returning to their neighborhoods to see what's left of their homes. One of the hardest-hit neighborhoods is Altadena [al tuh DEE nuh], which was ravaged by the Eaton Fire.

Title: Alec Baldwin sues New Mexico officials over handling of 'Rust' shooting case
Description: Actor Alec Baldwin has filed a civil lawsuit for malicious prosecution and civil rights violations in the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the Western movie Rust. (Image credit: Ramsay de Give/AP)

Title: Pizzagate' gunman killed by police in North Carolina, authorities say
Description: A man who fired a gun inside a restaurant in the nation's capital after a fake online conspiracy theory motivated him to do so nearly a decade ago was shot and killed by North Carolina police. (Image credit: Sathi Soma)

Title: Winter Storm Cora brings cold and snow to the Southern U.S.
Description: A major winter storm is expected to be the biggest in years as cold air moves in from the Arctic bringing snow and frigid temperatures across 20 Southern States. (Image credit: Brandon Bell)

Title: Trump loses Supreme Court appeal to block hush-money sentencing
Description: This was the only one of Trump's criminal charges to reach and complete a trial, making him the first former or future U.S. president to be convicted of criminal charges. (Image credit: Michael M. Santiago)

Title: FEMA fire administrator talks response and what recovery looks like for L.A. residents
Description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Dr. Lori- Moore-Merrell, the Fire Administrator for FEMA, about fighting -- and plans to rebuild after -- the fires in Los Angeles.

Title: He saved our lives.' A former US hostage reflects on Carter's legacy
Description: Jimmy Carter's four years in the White House were largely defined by an event that took place halfway through his term. On November 4th, 1979 Iranian college students took over the US Embassy in Tehran, and took 52 Americans hostage.For the next 444 days, the Carter administration tried to secure the hostages' release. In April, 1980 they even commissioned a rescue mission that ended in failure. While Carter was trying to end the hostage crisis, he was also campaigning for a second term. A year to the day after the Americans were taken hostage, Ronald Reagan beat Carter in a landslide.The hostage crisis played a key role in Carter's defeat. The Iranian Hostage crisis helped doom Jimmy Carter's presidency, but for some of the people he helped free,...

Title: A baby is born at sea on an overcrowded migrant boat
Description: a baby girl, born at sea on an overcrowded rubber dinghy, has been rescued with her mother.

Title: L.A. fires latest: Close to 200,000 people remain under mandatory evacuation
Description: As high winds persist, Los Angeles struggles with water and firefighting staffing challenges. Authorities say 'thousands' of homes and businesses are destroyed. At least five people have died.

Title: Altadena Town Council chair talks about disaster response from the Eaton fire
Description: NPR's Juana Summers talks with Victoria Knapp, chair of Altadena Town Council, about the destruction in her town from the Eaton fire.

Title: Carter to be laid to rest in Georgia following today's funeral service
Description: Former president Jimmy Carter will be laid to rest in his hometown of Plains, Ga. He died Dec. 29 at the age of 100, and was honored with a National Funeral Service in Washington, D.C.

Title: Lebanon chooses a new president after two years without one
Description: Lebanon's parliament chose the head of the country's armed forces, Joseph Aoun, to be its next president, a post that's been vacant since October 2022. (Image credit: Houssam Shbaro)

Title: Powerful winds fueling the California wildfires are expected through Friday
Description: Red flag warnings are in effect for parts of Los Angeles and Ventura counties, as the National Weather Service warns that powerful winds and low humidity will increase the risk of fire. (Image credit: David Swanson)

Title: What it is Like to Live and Report in Gaza
Description: Israel has prevented international journalists from entering Gaza, which means getting information from the territory is difficult. NPR has relied on producer Anas Baba who lives in and reports from Gaza to be our microphone. In a conversation with NPR's correspondent Israel Daniel Estrin, we hear about the daily challenges Baba faces in Gaza. For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

Title: PHOTOS: See the California wildfires' destructive force, in satellite images
Description: Satellite images show the extent of devastation from multiple wildfires burning in Los Angeles County after one day. The fires have killed at least five people and destroyed thousands of structures.

Title: Photos: Los Angeles wildfires threaten lives, homes and cultural landmarks
Description: The fires have forced mass evacuations. Firefighters are struggling to control a patchwork of deadly blazes that have killed at least five people and leveled entire communities. (Image credit: Ethan Swope)

Title: Billy Crystal, Paris Hilton, other celebrities share LA fire experiences, resources
Description: The California wildfires are burning in the middle of what's usually a busy awards season in Hollywood, home to many celebrities. (Image credit: Eric Thayer)

Title: Former President Jimmy Carter: The 'Fresh Air' interviews (Part 2)
Description: The 39th president spoke with Terry Gross in 1995, 2001 and 2005 about poetry, Sept. 11 and his concerns about how intertwined politics and religion had become. Carter died on Dec. 29 at age 100.

Title: Mail service is suspended, and trading floors are silent, in honor of Jimmy Carter
Description: Post offices are closed and mail delivery is suspended Thursday on the national day of mourning for former President Jimmy Carter. The stock market and some national parks are also closed. (Image credit: Nati Harnik)

Title: LA councilwoman Traci Park discusses the wildfires that have devastated the area
Description: Los Angeles councilwoman Traci Park, who represents the Pacific Palisades, joins the program to discuss the wildfires that have devastated the area.

Title: Wildfires upend lives in Southern California. And, Jimmy Carter's state funeral
Description: Wildfires drastically impact life in Southern California, destroying neighborhoods. Here's where things stand. And, what to expect from former President Jimmy Carter's state funeral today. (Image credit: Josie Huang)

Title: Raging Los Angeles fires sweep into the Hollywood Hills; at least 5 are dead
Description: The multiplying fires have killed at least five people, forced widespread evacuation orders and burned tens of thousands of acres, destroying homes, businesses and cultural landmarks. (Image credit: Apu Gomes)

Title: Imprisoned Belarus activist resurfaces after being incommunicado for over 700 days
Description: He was last heard from in February 2023. Since then, authorities haven't released any information about his condition and barred his lawyer from visits. (Image credit: Ramil Nasibulin)

Title: Here's what's behind Russia cutting off its last gas line to Europe
Description: A decades-long Russian-Ukrainian transit gas deal to Europe ended on Jan. 1. For now, the most acute effects are being felt in a region called Transnistria, on the eastern edge of Moldova. (Image credit: Akos Stiller)

Title: What's next for Canada? 5 questions will help decide the future after Trudeau
Description: We're in a unique situation in Canadian politics,' Shachi Kurl, president of the Angus Reid Institute, tells NPR. Voters need to replace a lame-duck leader — and cope with threats from Trump. (Image credit: DAVE CHAN/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: U.S. stock markets close to honor former President Jimmy Carter
Description: The New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq will both observe Thursday's national day of mourning in a Wall Street tradition dating back to 1865. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: All 5 living presidents expected to attend Jimmy Carter's National Cathedral funeral
Description: President Biden is expected to deliver a eulogy to former President Jimmy Carter at the National Cathedral service. (Image credit: Maansi Srivastava for NPR)

Title: Special ed students benefit from being integrated at school. It doesn't always happen
Description: Research shows including students with and without disabilities in the same classroom can benefit everyone. Two students with Down syndrome show what can be gained when that happens. (Image credit: Katrina Ward for NPR)

Title: Japanese crime leader pleads guilty to conspiring to sell nuclear materials to Iran
Description: Prosecutors said samples of the alleged nuclear material was weapons-grade, meaning enough of it would be suitable for use in a nuclear weapon.

Description: Firefighters battle several wildfires in the LA area, hundreds of dignitaries to gather for former President Carter's state funeral, and Republicans set a course for Trump's legislative agenda.

Title: How former President Jimmy Carter's hometown of Plains shaped his life
Description: After former President Jimmy Carter was voted out of office in 1980, he returned to his small hometown. Hear about how Plains, Georgia, shaped his remarkable life.

Title: DOJ tries to block plea agreement for alleged 9/11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammad
Description: In a highly unusual legal move, the Justice Department has asked a federal appeals court to stop alleged 9/11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammad from pleading guilty this Friday at Guantanamo -- even though two U.S. military courts have already rejected the Defense Secretary's attempt to block KSM's plea.

Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is tasked with writing and enforcing rules for the financial industry. How might the independent federal agency change under the Trump administration?

Title: Wildfires in the Los Angeles area force tens of thousands to flee
Description: Tens of thousands of people in the Los Angeles area have had to flee their homes, often very quickly, as strong winds fuel multiple wildfires.

Title: Hundreds of dignitaries to gather for former President Jimmy Carter's state funeral
Description: Today, all the living U.S. presidents will gather with hundreds of other dignitaries at the National Cathedral in Washington, D.C., for former President Jimmy Carter's state funeral.

Title: Will there be enough money to pay out insurance claims from the LA wildfires?
Description: The fires in Los Angeles have the potential to bankrupt the state's insurer-of-last resort for homes in places commercial insurers have fled.

Title: How New Orleans is coping following the Bourbon Street attack that killed 14
Description: It's been just over a week since the terror attack on Bourbon Street in New Orleans that killed 14 people. Now, the focus is shifting toward recovery for the injured and the community.

Title: An update on the deadly wildfires burning in the Los Angeles area
Description: Multiple major wildfires continue to burn out of control in the Los Angeles area, forcing thousands to evacuate. Hear the latest on the devastation and efforts to contain the blazes.

Title: Justice Department accuses 6 major landlords of keeping rents high
Description: The lawsuit arrives as U.S. renters continue to struggle. The latest figures show that half of American renters spent more than 30% of their income on rent and utilities in 2022, an all-time high. (Image credit: Jose Luis Magana)

Title: The NHL postpones a game and the Lakers coach evacuates his family amid LA fires
Description: The fires burning across Los Angeles have affected tens of thousands of people, including athletes and staff for the city's sports teams. Pasadena's iconic Rose Bowl was under evacuation warning. (Image credit: Harry How)

Title: Fire hydrants ran dry in Pacific Palisades as a major wildfire raged
Description: Janisse Quiñones, CEO of the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, said the fight to contain the flames has put immense strain on the system. (Image credit: Etienne Laurent)

Title: The latest on the fires burning across southern California
Description: Destructive winds not seen in more than a decade have led to multiple fires burning across Southern California. Here's the latest information.

Title: A 9/11 plea deal is in doubt: Unpacking the legal drama
Description: The DOJ has asked to stop the alleged 9/11 mastermind from pleading guilt at Guantanamo -- even though two U.S. military courts already rejected the Defense Secretary's attempt to block the plea.

Title: The power struggle taking place in the Israeli-occupied West Bank
Description: The Palestinian Authority, which governs the West Bank, has spent weeks weeks besieging the Jenin refugee camp. The tussle for power is also a fight over different visions for the Palestinian people.

Title: The Palisades fire continues its path of destruction in Los Angeles
Description: At least two people are dead as a result of the wildfires in Los Angeles, more than 1,000 homes destroyed. Officials now worry about manpower and water shortages.

Title: Syrians are visiting the once off-limits seaside Assad family villa
Description: Syrians are now visiting the seaside villa of the ousted President Bashir al-Assad. The compound had been off-limits since it was built for the Assad family 50 years ago.

Title: Is Democracy Holding Up in South Korea?
Description: Authorities in South Korea are continuing to try to arrest impeached South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, following his failed declaration of martial law over a month ago. As the country continues to be mired in political crisis, analyst are studying the health of the country's democracy. And as our correspondent in Seoul tells us, they're drawing comparisons to recent events in the U.S.

Title: An American held during the Iran hostage crisis talks about Jimmy Carter's legacy
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with Barry Rosen, one of the 52 Americans held in Iran during the hostage crisis from 1979 to 1981, on President Jimmy Carter's quest to bring about their safe release.

Title: Wildfires displace thousands and ravage greater Los Angeles
Description: Extremely dry conditions coupled with high winds have led to an explosive wildfire situation in southern California. Multiple fires have erupted across the Los Angeles area since Tuesday. Tens of thousands of people have had to evacuate, and firefighters are struggling to contain the flames.Adria Kloke is one of the of people who has had to flee. She packed up her belongings, along with her cat, and left her home in Pacific Palisades on Tuesday. Title: Fleeing the California fires
Description: Pacific Palisades resident Adria Kloke shares her experience of fleeing the wildfires in California on Tuesday.

Title: In D.C.'s bitter cold, a homeless shelter offers hot food and some hope
Description: NPR visited a homeless shelter in Washington, D.C., to see how residents and staff are faring during a cold emergency. The shelter is busy year-round, though the frigid weather brings in more people. (Image credit: Dee Dwyer)

Title: What are the Santa Ana winds and how are they impacting the L.A. wildfires?
Description: Although the Santa Anas are a routine part of life for people living in southern California, the winds are particularly violent and destructive this time around, experts say. (Image credit: Apu Gomes)

Title: Here's where things stand for seven major landmarks in the Los Angeles fires
Description: The fires raging across Los Angeles are putting some cultural institutions in danger. (Image credit: David Swanson)

Title: The Southern California wildfires through the eyes of the community
Description: Destructive winds not seen for more than a decade are fanning multiple fires across Los Angeles and Ventura Counties. Tens of thousands of people have been forced to evacuate, schools across the area are closed, and power lines have been shut off in parts of the region to protect against further ignitions. (Image credit: Josie Huang)

Title: Justice Department wants to release only part of its report on Trump cases
Description: Prosecutors dropped the two criminal cases against Trump after he won the 2024 election, and the final report by Smith may be the last chance for prosecutors to explain their decisions. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: Trump asks the Supreme Court to block his sentencing in hush money case
Description: President-elect Donald Trump is scheduled to be sentenced on Jan. 10 in New York. His latest legal move to block sentencing comes after a New York appeals court rejected a similar appeal Tuesday. (Image credit: Scott Olson)

Title: A looming 'demographic cliff': Fewer college students and ultimately fewer graduates
Description: The long-predicted downturn in the number of 18-year-olds is almost here. And it isn't just a problem for higher education. It's a looming crisis for the economy. (Image credit: Photo illustration by Camilla Forte)

Title: As winter storms strike, airlines scramble to de-ice planes and keep them flying
Description: A pair of powerful major winter storms is disrupting the U.S. air travel system this week. That leaves airlines no choice but to de-ice their planes before takeoff to keep them in the air. (Image credit: Rick Bowmer)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Industry watchers see Meta's end of fact-checking as move to appease Trump, annual winter respiratory virus season returns with a vengeance, and Los Angeles wildfires force thousands of evacuations.

Title: Jimmy Carter in 2007 addressed criticism of his book 'Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid'
Description: Hear an excerpt from an interview where former President Jimmy Carter addressed criticism of his 2006 book about the Israeli/Palestinian conflict titled 'Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid.'

Title: Los Angeles wildfires force thousands of evacuations as state of emergency declared
Description: Los Angeles County faces at least three out-of-control wildfires fueled by unusually strong Santa Ana winds. Thousands have been forced to evacuate and a state of emergency has been declared.

Title: Minneapolis and DOJ reach agreement on police reforms following George Floyd murder
Description: Nearly five years after George Floyd was killed, Minneapolis has promised to reform its police department. Assistant Attorney General Kristen Clarke talks about the agreement between the city and DOJ.

Title: After Assad, how can Syrians reconcile to rebuild the nation?
Description: After the downfall of the Assad regime, how can Syrians reconcile and form an inclusive government for all citizens? NPR speaks with Mona Yacoubian with the United States Institute of Peace.

Title: Medical debt will be removed from your credit report
Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is removing medical debt from credit reports. NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Benedic Ippolito, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, about the move.

Title: Greenland member of Parliament addresses Trump's interest in purchasing the territory
Description: NPR's Michel Martin asks Kuno Fencker, a member of Greenland's Parliament, about Donald Trump Jr.'s visit and his father's desire for the U.S. to buy the territory.

Title: First international commercial flight since Assad's ouster lands in Syria
Description: The Qatar Airways flight landed at Damascus International Airport. Many passengers were Syrian nationals coming come for the first time in more than a decade. (Image credit: Omar Sanadiki)

Title: Photos: Thousands in Los Angeles evacuate as wind-fueled Palisades Fire quickly worsens
Description: More than 30,000 people in Los Angeles County have been ordered to evacuate as the Palisades Fire blazed through the Pacific Palisades community, fueled by intense Santa Ana winds. (Image credit: Etienne Laurent)

Title: The Palisades Fire continues to grow due to strong winds and dry conditions
Description: Unusually high winds and dry conditions are driving the Palisades Fire in Southern California. More than 30,000 people are under mandatory evacuation orders.

Description: In Washington, D.C., the federal government is closed – as are most of the schools in the area. That's because the first major snow storm in about three years barreled in Sunday night. Meanwhile, the Southern U.S. is preparing for another storm that could paralyze parts of Texas, Arkansas and Northern Louisiana. And Southern California is preparing for 'life threatening, destructive gusts' driving wildfires. Title: Trump doubles down today on his threat to impose steep tariffs on Canada
Description: President-elect Trump doubled down on his threat to impose economic pressure against Canada. The warning comes one day after Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced his plans to step down.

Title: Man who exploded Cybertruck in Las Vegas used ChatGPT in planning, police say
Description: The highly decorated soldier who exploded a Tesla Cybertruck outside the Trump hotel in Las Vegas used generative AI including ChatGPT to help plan the attack, Las Vegas police said Tuesday. (Image credit: Las Vegas Police Department)

Title: Cash is disintegrating due to overuse in Gaza. New businesses are repairing it
Description: Cash, the most precious commodity in Gaza, is disintegrating from overuse, and new banknotes have not been sent to Gaza during the war. That has led to e-banking and cash repair services.

Title: Wild weather brings snow to the South and Santa Ana winds to the West
Description: As the South prepped for snow and more cold starting Wednesday, residents in Southern California faced off with hurricane-strength winds. (Image credit: Julio Cortez)

Title: The Significance of Bread Lines in Syria
Description: Weeks ago, a new interim government in Syria was formed in the wake of the regime of Bashar al-Assad being toppled. And now that new government faces myriad challenges in holding the government together and keeping it running. Our correspondent in Damascus takes us to a bakery to show us one of the most visible signs of the new government's struggle, long bread lines. (Image credit: ARIS MESSINIS)

Title: Jean-Marie Le Pen, former far-right political leader in France, dies at 96
Description: Jean Marie Le Pen, the founder of France's post war far right movement died on Tuesday at the age of 96. He was repeatedly charged with hate speech, notably over comments about the Holocaust.

Title: What to know about Trump and his keen interest in Greenland
Description: President-elect Donald Trump has said multiple times that the U.S. should buy Greenland, an autonomous territory of Denmark. The sparsely populated island is geopolitically important and mineral-rich. (Image credit: Claire Harbage)

Title: Life threatening' windstorm triggers wildfire in Southern California
Description: Southern California hasn't seen significant rainfall since last April, and a pileup of dry fuel in combination with the winds has the region on edge. A mandatory evacuation order was issued for the Palisades. (Image credit: Ethan Swope)

Title: U.S. declares genocide in Sudan
Description: The Biden administration said it has determined that Sudan's paramilitary group, the Rapid Support Forces, is committing genocide in the country's ongoing civil war.

Title: Minneapolis agrees to additional court-ordered oversight of its police department
Description: The Minneapolis Police Department must make major reforms under a federal consent decree. That comes nearly five years after a Minneapolis police officer murdered George Floyd.

Title: Florida judge blocks release of special counsel report on Trump cases
Description: Florida federal judge Aileen Cannon ordered the Justice Department not to share Jack Smith's final report until a federal appeals court resolves the legal fight. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: The U.S. says Sudan's rebel forces have committed genocide
Description: The Biden administration said the Sudanese Rapid Support Forces group and its proxies are committing genocide in a civil war with the country's military that has killed tens of thousands of people. (Image credit: Sam Mednick)

Title: A Dutch project publicizes the names of half a million suspected Nazi collaborators
Description: The names of some 425,000 suspected Dutch collaborators went online 80 years after the Holocaust ended, making them accessible to historians and descendants as the country grapples with its past. (Image credit: Keystone/Getty Images)

Title: 2 bodies found in JetBlue plane's landing gear compartment at a Florida airport
Description: The bodies were located in the wheel well area at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. It's the second time over the past month that a body has been found in the wheel well of an airplane. (Image credit: Chris O'Meara)

Title: In a workforce transformed by war, Ukrainian women are now working in coal mines
Description: War has changed Ukraine's workforce, especially in heavy industry and mining. With men conscripted to fight the war against Russia, women have started working in traditionally male jobs. (Image credit: Michael Robinson Chávez for NPR)

Title: Jean-Marie Le Pen, French fiery far-right leader, dies at 96
Description: Le Pen was convicted numerous times of antisemitism, discrimination and inciting racial violence. But the nativist ideas that propelled his popularity remain ascendant in today's France and beyond. (Image credit: Kamil Zihnioglu)

Title: Jimmy Carter's funeral services begin in DC. And, photos from the major winter storm
Description: Former President Jimmy Carter's funeral services begin in Washington, D.C., today, and NPR will have special coverage of the events. And, photos from the winter storm plowing through parts of the U.S. (Image credit: Brynn Anderson)

Title: What America's top economists are saying about AI and inequality
Description: Planet Money attended the annual meeting of American economists — and the most popular topic this year was artificial intelligence.

Title: Jimmy Carter's funeral services begin in Washington, D.C., today
Description: The next stop in former President Jimmy Carter's six days of funeral services is Washington, D.C., where he will lie in state in the U.S. Capitol through Thursday morning. (Image credit: Jon Cherry)

Title: Strong earthquake kills dozens in western China near Mount Everest
Description: A strong earthquake killed dozens of people in Tibet on Tuesday and left many others trapped as dozens of aftershocks shook the high-altitude region of western China and across the border in Nepal. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announces resignation
Description: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has announced he is stepping down ahead of this year's general election. He had faced mounting pressure to resign — from both allies and opponents.

Title: How ISIS is adapting its tactics to survive
Description: Is ISIS having a resurgence? NPR's A Martinez talks to Aaron David Miller, senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, about how ISIS is adapting its tactics to survive.

Title: How ISIS is adapting its tactics to survive
Description: Is ISIS having a resurgence? NPR's A Martinez talks to Aaron David Miller, senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, about how ISIS is adapting its tactics to survive.

Title: Orthodox Christmas takes on special meaning in Lebanon this year
Description: Many Orthodox Christians celebrate Christmas in January, not December. In Lebanon, Christians say the holiday is extra poignant for them this year.

Title: In 2007 interview, Jimmy Carter discusses what he faced after losing reelection
Description: Hear excerpts from a 2007 NPR interview with former President Jimmy Carter talking about the stark question he faced after failing to win reelection: what to do with the rest of his life.

Title: Syria's interim government faces a new, serious challenge — bread lines
Description: Bread lines have become a feature of the new Syria, posing a critical challenge to the country's rebel rulers who ousted President Bashar al-Assad last month.

Title: Growing number of Colombians are fighting — and dying — in conflicts around the world
Description: More and more former members of Colombia's armed forces are fighting and dying as mercenaries around the world.

Title: Virginia elections could determine if Democrats hold slim majority in Legislature
Description: Special elections in Virginia could decide whether Democrats maintain their control of the Legislature as the commonwealth heads into a governor's race this fall.

Title: Hamas and Israel are negotiating the release of hostages from Gaza
Description: Israel and Hamas are eyeing a hostage release and ceasefire deal before Donald Trump's inauguration.

Title: Former adviser and analyst discusses why key committee was split on U.S. Steel deal
Description: Why was the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States split on allowing or blocking Nippon Steel from buying U.S. Steel? NPR's Michel Martin asks one of the committee's former advisers.

Title: Ski patrollers strike at Utah's Park City Mountain resort
Description: Ski-industry giant Vail resorts is struggling with a strike by ski patrollers at Park City Mountain resort in Utah, their biggest property. Skiers are complaining about delays and unsafe conditions.

Title: Morning Edition colleagues share snow-day traditions
Description: With much of the central and eastern U.S. blanketed with snow, our Morning Edition colleagues share a few beloved snow day traditions.

Title: Minneapolis, DOJ agree on police reforms in wake of George Floyd murder
Description: The city of Minneapolis and the U.S. Department of Justice have agreed on a consent decree which calls for the Minneapolis Police Department to make extensive reforms. The agreement comes five years after the death of George Floyd caused protests around the city and the world.

Title: U.K. leader Starmer slams 'lies and misinformation' after attacks from Elon Musk
Description: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Monday condemned 'lies and misinformation' that he said are undermining U.K. democracy, in response to a barrage of attacks on his government from Elon Musk. (Image credit: Leon Neal/AP)

Title: Minneapolis agrees to overhaul police training and policies following Floyd murder
Description: The Minneapolis City Council on Monday approved an agreement with the federal government to overhaul the city's police training and use-of-force policies in the wake of the murder of George Floyd. (Image credit: Jeff Wheeler/AP)

Title: Rudy Giuliani is held in contempt of court in $148 million defamation case
Description: Rudy Giuliani was found in contempt of court for failing to properly respond to requests for information as he turned over assets to satisfy a defamation ruling granted to two Georgia poll workers. (Image credit: Adam Gray)

Title: The National Zoo's giant pandas make the most of DC's snow
Description: The two giant pandas were seen on camera playing around in the snowfall that blanketed much of the Midwest and mid-Atlantic on Monday. (Image credit: National Zoo)

Title: First bird flu death reported in the U.S., according to the CDC
Description: Health officials in Louisiana say a person there has died after catching bird flu. This marks the first reported death in the U.S. from the virus during the current outbreak. (Image credit: Callista Images)

Title: Elon Musk has been trolling British politicians, stirring anger and concern
Description: Fixated on a UK sex abuse scandal from 15 years ago, Elon Musk has been trolling British officials, prompting a rebuke from the prime minister and worry over what this portends for U.S. policy.

Title: It will now cost up to $9 to drive into New York City
Description: Motorists driving into many parts of Manhattan will now pay as much as $9, as part of a new congestion pricing plan to eliminate traffic and pay for improvements to mass transit.

Title: In Syria, a once-privileged Muslim sect is now targeted and afraid
Description: Alawites in Syria are facing a violent backlash, stoking fears of wider sectarian instability in a divided Syria after the fall of the Assad regime.

Title: Pentagon agrees to settle historic lawsuit with LGBTQ+ veterans over discharge status
Description: The Pentagon has agreed to settle a class action lawsuit involving about 35,000 LGBTQ+ veterans that will help them get benefits like health care and disability. (Image credit: Daniel Slim)

Title: 32 dolphins have died since an oil spill near southern Russia, experts say
Description: A dolphin rescue center said most of the dead dolphins were from the endangered Azov species. (Image credit: Krasnodar Gov. Veniamin Kondraty)

Title: A winter storm moves across the U.S., causing disruptions and snowball fights
Description: Millions of Americans are under weather advisories today as a winter storm blasts through the middle of the country.

Title: What may be next after a federal court struck down the FCC's net neutrality rules
Description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Stanford Law Professor Barbara van Schewick about a federal court's decision to strike down the Biden administration's net neutrality protections.

Title: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will step down once his party has a new leader
Description: Under pressure from voters and his own members of parliament, Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced Monday that he will step down once his Liberal Party names a sucessor.

Title: Biden visits New Orleans after Jan. 1 attack
Description: President Joe Biden will travel to New Orleans on Monday and attend a prayer service for the 14 victims of the New Year's Day attack.

Title: The Epicenter of the COVID Outbreak Five Years Later
Description: We go to the city were there the COVID-19 global pandemic started five years ago, Wuhan, China. We find that security is still tight and trauma is still pervasive. We look at what has changed— and what hasn't— since the 'mysterious illness' first emerged.

Title: U.S. transfers 11 Yemeni prisoners from Guantánamo to Oman
Description: The Biden administration's move leaves just 15 detainees at the U.S. military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Oman will help resettle the men and provide security monitoring. (Image credit: Thomas Watkins)

Title: Hamas and Israel are negotiating the release of 34 hostages from Gaza
Description: The deal would secure release of a third of the approximately 100 hostages who remain in Gaza, including two dual U.S.-Israeli nationals. In return, Israel would release some Palestinian prisoners. (Image credit: Amir Levy/Getty Images)

Title: Millions of public workers are set to get higher Social Security benefits. Here's why
Description: Public service workers including some teachers, firefighters, police officers may soon see their Social Security payments increase by hundreds of dollars. (Image credit: Kent Nishimura)

Title: Lessons from self-inflicted blows to democracy in South Korea and the U.S.
Description: The brief declaration of martial law in South Korea last month has drawn comparisons to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. The attempted power grabs could hold lessons for other democracies. (Image credit: Anthony Wallace)

Title: Canada's Justin Trudeau says he will resign as party leader and prime minister
Description: Trudeau's decision after almost a decade in power sets the stage for a succession fight to select a new prime minister. (Image credit: Dave Chan)

Title: Photos: See the impact a major winter storm is having on U.S.
Description: Winter storm warnings have ben declared from Illinois to New Jersey. And some areas will get a lot of snow. They will also get freezing rain and ice, blustery winds and frigid temperatures. (Image credit: Joshua A. Bickel)

Title: How Jan. 6 will be different this year. And, who took home a Golden Globe award
Description: Today, four years since the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, President-elect Donald Trump's victory is scheduled to be certified by Congress. And, the big wins and surprises at the 82nd Golden Globes. (Image credit: Brendan Smialowski/Pool)

Title: Biden bans new offshore oil and gas drilling in most federal waters
Description: President Joe Biden is moving to ban new offshore oil and gas drilling in most U.S. coastal waters, an effort to block possible action by the incoming Trump administration to expand offshore drilling. (Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)

Title: Pictures of Odesa, as it tangles with a complex web of Russian and Ukrainian heritage
Description: Photographer Michael Robinson Chávez visits a city in Ukraine that was partly famous as a site for Russian travelers and intellectuals, but since 2022 has come under Russian attack. (Image credit: Michael Robinson Chávez for NPR)

Title: Snowstorms close schools and offices across a large swath of the U.S.
Description: Several governors have issued states of emergency as 6 to 12 inches of snow are expected from Ohio to Washington, D.C. (Image credit: Joshua A. Bickel)

Title: Official tours of the U.S. Capitol building do not mention the Jan. 6 riot
Description: Nearly 2 million tourists visit the U.S. Capitol each year and learn about the building's art and history. What they don't hear on official tours is what happened on Jan. 6, 2021.

Title: As people mourn after French Quarter attack, festival season begins in New Orleans
Description: Festival season starts in New Orleans today with the first Mardi Gras parade as people there are still processing last week's terror attack in the French Quarter.

Title: Locals in Syria's Golan Heights fear Israeli operations in area could be a land grab
Description: Locals in Syria's Golan Heights told NPR that they fear a recent Israeli military operation in the area could be a land grab. Israel says the move is necessary to secure its borders.

Title: A Capitol Police officer assaulted during the Jan. 6 riot says he feels 'betrayed'
Description: Former Capitol Police officer Aquilino Gonell was repeatedly assaulted during the Jan. 6, 2021 riot. Since Donald Trump's reelection, he says he feels 'betrayed.'

Title: FBI says suspect in New Orleans attack that killed 14 recently visited the city twice
Description: The man who crashed a truck through the French Quarter in New Orleans killing 14 people, visited the city twice before the attack. Authorities say the Texas native also went to Egypt and Canada.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: A Capitol Police officer assaulted during the Jan. 6 riot says he feels 'betrayed,' CNN is in court Monday fighting a defamation lawsuit, and we take a look at the 2025 Golden Globe winners.

Title: Indonesia launches free meals program to fight stunting
Description: Indonesia's new government started an ambitious project to feed nearly 90 million children and pregnant women to fight malnutrition and stunting, as critics question whether the program is affordable. (Image credit: Dita Alangkara)

Title: FBI says suspect in New Orleans attack twice visited the city to conduct surveillance
Description: The FBI says the man who allegedly carried out the New Year's Day attack visited the city in October and November, and recorded video of the area he aimed to target using 'smart glasses.' (Image credit: Gerald Herbert)

Title: Millions face snow and ice as a major winter storm moves across the U.S.
Description: A major winter storm is bringing ice, snow and freezing rain from the Plains to the East Coast through Tuesday. (Image credit: Jeff Roberson)

Title: NPR photos around the world that moved us in 2024
Description: There have been touching moments — sometimes away from the headlines, and the front lines — that have moved the world this year. (Image credit: Claire Harbage)

Title: Congestion pricing begins in NYC in a high stakes test for the model's U.S. viability
Description: Congestion pricing was introduced on Sunday morning in the center of New York City — despite a late attempt by New Jersey to stop it in court. (Image credit: Bebeto Matthews/AP)

Title: Longtime captain's retirement begins a new chapter for a West Virginia ferry ride
Description: The longtime pilot of the only Ohio River ferry in West Virginia is retiring. We'll take a ride with him. (This story first aired on Morning Edition on December 25, 2024.)

Title: New Orleans residents say they won't let an act of terror destroy the city's spirit
Description: Following the New Year's Day truck attack in New Orleans, people who live in the French Quarter discuss what's ahead for them and their neighborhood.

Title: Trump wants to address homelessness by working with states to ban street camping
Description: President-elect Trump wants to overhaul how the U.S. manages record-high homelessness. It could shift billions in federal funding away from housing and toward drug addiction programs. (This story first aired on Morning Edition on Jan. 3, 2025.)

Title: CNN goes on trial over its report alleging 'black market' for Afghan rescues
Description: A CNN story about a 'black market' for rescuing people from Afghanistan after the Taliban takeover is at the heart of a defamation trial that opens Monday in Florida. (Image credit: CNN via Internet Archive/Screenshot by NPR)

Title: As Trump rewrites history, victims of the Jan. 6 riot say they feel 'betrayed'
Description: A police officer defended the Capitol from violent rioters on Jan. 6. With President-elect Donald Trump poised to pardon the rioters, he now asks, 'what did I risk my life for?' (Image credit: Brent Stirton)

Title: Heavy snow brings widespread disruption across the U.K.
Description: Heavy snow and freezing rain has brought widespread disruption across the U.K., with several major airports forced to suspend flights and many key roads in the north of England unnavigable. (Image credit: Scott Heppell)

Title: Venezuela opposition leader Edmundo González embarks on international tour
Description: González, who the United States recognized as the winner of last year's presidential election in Venezuela, kicked off an international tour on Saturday that will take him to Washington. (Image credit: Natacha Pisarenko)

Title: South Korean protesters brave cold to demand Yoon's ouster as detention deadline looms
Description: South Koreans rallied overnight near the residence of impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol calling for his arrest, as authorities prepared to renew their efforts to detain him. (Image credit: Ahn Young-joon)

Title: President Biden blocked the U.S. steel deal. How are people in Pennsylvania reacting?
In Lebanon, the Litani River demarcates identity — and war
Description: The Litani river descends from Lebanon's snow-capped mountains into dusty towns, then bisects the country and empties out into the Mediterranean. Along the way, it serves as a lifeline and boundary demarcating religion, environments, and war.

Title: Services honoring former president Jimmy Carter begin today in Georgia
The Colorado Dream' podcast documents the struggle for LGBTQ equality in the state
Jurassic footprints are discovered on a 'dinosaur highway' in southern England
Description: The 166-million-year-old footprint tracks, found at a quarry in southern England, mark one of the largest discoveries in decades.

Title: A storm will bring heavy snow and dangerous ice from the Plains to the East Coast
Description: This weekend's storm is expected to impact 62 million Americans through Monday. Heavy snow, ice, rain and severe thunderstorms will be unleashed from the Plains to the East Coast. (Image credit: NWS Weather Prediction Center)

Title: FBI investigates New Orleans attack as terrorism, Las Vegas motive remains unclear
Description: The FBI is investigating the Jan. 1 attack in New Orleans as an act of terrorism while the motivation for the Jan 1. truck explosion in Las Vegas is still unclear but appears to be mental illness.

Title: House and Senate majority leaders set the agenda for early weeks of a new Congress
Description: The new Republican majorities in the House and Senate plan to move border legislation and cabinet confirmations first, with tax bills coming later this year.

Title: Muslims in Houston are worried about backlash from the New Orleans attack
Description: The suspect in the Jan. 1 attack in New Orleans was reportedly a Muslim from Houston, which has one of the country's largest and most organized Islamic communities.

Description: The push to reopen Damascus International Airport highlights the challenges facing Syria's new leaders in rebuilding the country.

Title: Funeral events for President Jimmy Carter begin today in his hometown of Plains, Georgia
Description: A motorcade with the body of Pres. Jimmy Carter travels to his hometown of Plains, Ga., and then on to Atlanta Saturday.

Title: Vehicular attacks are not new. But preventing them has been a big challenge
Description: For decades, individuals and terrorist groups have used vehicles to carry out deadly attacks. But installing safeguards hasn't always been successful. (Image credit: Jack Brook)

Title: Seeking to heal the country, Jimmy Carter pardoned men who evaded the Vietnam War draft
Description: The pardon was one of the defining presidential moments for Jimmy Carter, who died Dec. 29 at the age of 100. The move was pilloried by members of the military and conservative politicians.

Title: Funeral services for former President Jimmy Carter start today in Georgia
Description: The first day of memorial services for former President Jimmy Carter begins today in his hometown of Plains, Ga., and will include stops at the Georgia State Capitol and the Carter Center in Atlanta. (Image credit: Alex Wroblewski)

Title: Japanese woman who was the world's oldest person at 116 has died
Description: Tomiko Itooka, a Japanese woman who was the world's oldest person according to Guinness World Records, has died, an Ashiya city official said Saturday. She was 116. (Image credit: AP)

Title: The potato-shaped loophole in free trade
Description: Ever since free trade opened up between the US and Mexico in the 1990s, trillions of dollars of goods have been going back and forth between the two countries, from cars to strawberries to MRI machines to underwear. But one major exception has been fresh American potatoes.Today on the show, we tell the trade saga of the American potato. For more than 25 years, there was a place that American potatoes could not go to freely. A place that the entire American potato industry was desperate to access. A vast, untapped market: Mexico.But standing in their way – the Mexican potato lobby and a trade loophole.This episode was hosted by Erika Beras and Jeff Guo. It was produced by Willa Rubin and edited by Meg Cramer. It was fact-checked by Sierra Juarez. Engineering by C...

Title: The soldier who died in Cybertruck explosion wrote it was intended as a 'wakeup call'
Description: Matthew Livelsberger, a 37-year-old Green Beret from Colorado, also wrote in a note that he needed to 'cleanse my mind' of the lives lost of people he knew and 'the burden of the lives I took.' (Image credit: Bizuayehu Tesfaye)

Title: The security failures that worsened the New Year's attack in New Orleans
Description: Bollards meant to close roads off to cars have been an issue in New Orleans for years. Why did officials ignore this for so long, and what more could be done to keep crowds there safe?

Title: Lessons from South Korea's (and the U.S.'s) self-inflicted blows to democracy
Description: South Korea's political crisis began a month ago with the brief declaration of martial law. It's a recent example of power grabs in established democracies that holds lessons for other nations.

Title: New Orleans moves forward after New Year's Day attack
Description: In New Orleans, it's been several days since the New Year's Day truck attack in the French Quarter. As residents and tourists grapple with what happened, people are also trying to get back to normal.

Title: Trump will be sentenced Jan. 10 in New York case, days before his inauguration
Description: The decision also comes after the judge in the case ruled last month that Trump isn't immune from his conviction. (Image credit: Rebecca Noble)

Title: The attack in New Orleans reveals ISIS' influence lingers, experts say
Description: The man behind the New Year's Day attack in New Orleans said in videos that he was inspired by ISIS and had joined the group this summer. This attack shows ISIS' resonance and resilience persists. (Image credit: STR)

Title: Biden made diversifying the federal bench a top priority. Here's a look at his legacy
Description: President Biden's judicial picks have included the first Black woman to the U.S. Supreme Court, women of color to federal appeals courts and openly LGBTQ judges to serve on the federal bench. (Image credit: Shawn Thew)

Title: Study: Cash handouts have a dramatic impact on the deadliest infectious disease
Description: A program in Brazil that give a monthly cash sum to families living in poverty has an unexpected — and welcome result. A new study shows that it is dramatically reducing tuberculosis rates. (Image credit: Stefano Figalo/Brazil Photos/LightRocket via Getty Images)

Title: An aspiring nurse, a football star, a single mother and a father of 2 killed in New Orleans attack
Description: Officials have not yet released the names of the 14 people killed in the New Orleans New Year's Day truck attack, but their families and friends have started sharing their stories. (Image credit: Jack Brook)

Title: FBI says deadly New Orleans attack suspect acted alone. And, the House speaker vote
Description: Why the FBI believes Shamsud-Din Jabbar, the suspect behind the deadly New Orleans attack on New Year's Day, acted alone. And, how Mike Johnson's House Speaker vote could get derailed. (Image credit: George Walker IV)

Title: The U.S. Surgeon General wants cancer warnings on alcohol. Here's why
Description: Drinking alcohol raises the risk of developing seven types of cancer, according to a new advisory from U.S. Surgeon General Vivek Murthy. (Image credit: David J. Phillip)

Title: Investigators have a clearer picture of a Texas man accused of New Orleans attack
Description: Authorities in New Orleans and Texas are piecing together why a man drove a pick-up truck down Bourbon Street on New Year's Day -- killing 14 and injuring dozens of others.

Title: A record number of migrants reached the Canary Islands by sea in 2024, Spain says
Description: The number beats the previous record, set in 2023, as a recent report also points at a peak in the number of deaths recorded in the dangerous Atlantic migration route. (Image credit: Antonio Sempere)

Title: For angry airline passengers, an apologist-in-chief smooths things over
Description: In this week's StoryCorps, we hear from a former Southwest Airlines employee whose job was to apologize to customers who had a bad travel experience.

Title: Myanmar's civil war has killed thousands -- yet it feels like a forgotten crisis
Description: A civil war in Myanmar has displaced millions, killed or maimed thousands more and left the country in poverty. Now China is flexing its muscle to protect interests in the region.

Title: Golan Heights villagers say homes were raided during Israeli security operations
Description: Villagers in Syria's Golan Heights have told NPR that Israeli troops have raided their homes and confiscated weapons. Israel says its military operation in the area is to ensure border security.

Title: Trump wants to address homelessness by working with states to ban street camping
Description: President-elect Trump wants to overhaul how the U.S. manages record-high homelessness. It could shift billions in federal funding away from housing and toward drug addiction programs.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: New Orleans' Bourbon Street reopens as the attack investigation goes on. Congress readies for a House speaker vote. Golan Heights villagers say homes were raided during an Israeli security operation.

Title: Assessing the Damage at Lebanon's Historical Sites
Description: Part of a Crusader castle collapsed. An 18th century minaret toppled. Church mosaics burned. Israeli airstrikes have damaged priceless antiquities across Lebanon & Syria during it's war with Hezbollah. With a ceasefire now in place, archaeologists are trying to assess damage to UNESCO World Heritage Sites. We visit some.

Title: 2 dead and 18 injured in Southern California plane crash
Description: Two people died and 18 were injured Thursday when a small plane crashed through the roof of a furniture manufacturing building in Southern California, police said. (Image credit: Jeff Gritchen/AP)

Title: Photos: Bourbon Street reopens in New Orleans after truck attack
Description: Bourbon Street re-opened in New Orleans Thursday afternoon, more than 24 hours after Wednesday morning's attack by a Texas man driving a Ford pickup truck plowed into a crowd of New Year's revelers. (Image credit: Halle Parker)

Title: Can we prevent deadly truck attacks like the one in New Orleans?
Description: New Orleans is still reeling from the New Year's Day attack that killed 14 people on Bourbon Street. We ask a counterterrorism expert how attacks like this can be prevented and hear the latest from New Orleans. (Image credit: ANDREW CABALLERO-REYNOLDS)

Title: Still on the hunt, the FBI shares new details about pipe bombs placed ahead of Jan. 6
Description: Officials are still trying to identify the person who placed bombs outside of the Democratic National Committee and the Republican National Committee offices in 2021. Now they have fresh details. (Image credit: FBI)

Title: Italy summons Iranian ambassador to demand release of journalist Cecilia Sala
Description: On Thursday in Rome, Italy's foreign ministry summoned the Iranian ambassador, demanding the immediate release of Italian reporter Cecilia Sala from Iran's notorious Evin prison.

Title: The oldest living Olympic medal winner, Ágnes Keleti, has died at age 103
Description: Keleti, who was also a Holocaust survivor, was hospitalized in critical condition with pneumonia on Dec. 25. She died Thursday morning in Budapest, the Hungarian state news agency reported. (Image credit: Laszlo Balogh)

Title: How Trump can end the war in Ukraine, according to a former ambassador
Description: NPR's Andrew Limbong speaks with Michael McFaul, former U.S. Ambassador to Russia, about his recent piece in Foreign Affairs, 'How Trump Can End the War in Ukraine.'

Title: A father talks about losing his 18-year-old son in the New Orleans attack
Description: Kareem Badawi just finished his first semester at the University of Alabama, where was studying engineering. His father Belal Badawi says he was an 18 year old full of life.

Title: Ukrainian soldiers and shopkeepers hold on as Russia's siege of Pokrovsk tightens
Description: Ukrainian forces are fighting to hold on to the key city of Pokrovsk, in one of the fiercest battles in eastern Ukraine, but commanders admit the Russians have more troops and firepower. (Image credit: Anton Shtuka for NPR)

Title: FBI now says the suspect in the deadly New Orleans truck attack acted alone
Description: Shamsud-Din Jabbar, the driver of the pickup truck who plowed into a crowd in New Orleans on New Year's Day, killing at least 14 people, acted alone, the FBI said Thursday. (Image credit: George Walker IV)

Title: Army IDs man killed in Tesla Cybertruck explosion outside Trump's Las Vegas hotel
Description: Authorities identified the man killed in the Tesla Cybertruck explosion Wednesday as Master Sgt. Matthew Alan Livelsberger. He entered the Army in 2012 and was a U.S. Army Special Operations Soldier. (Image credit: David Becker for the Washington Post)

Title: An 'Arctic outbreak' will send a chill through much of the U.S. Here's how to prepare
Description: Blasts of Arctic air are poised to bring below-average temperatures to much of the central and eastern U.S. throughout the first half of January. Here's what to expect and how to prepare. (Image credit: Jeff Swensen)

Title: With fears about the future, some Syrian women find comfort in beauty parlors
Description: In Damascus beauty parlors, Syrian women hope looking good will help them feel better about a future they fear. (Story aired on ATC on Dec. 31, 2024.)

Title: Details on the deadly attack in New Orleans. And, Amazon workers return to the office
Description: The attack in New Orleans left at least 15 people dead and dozens more injured. Here's what we know so far about the driver who plowed through the crowd. And, Amazon workers return to the office. (Image credit: Michael DeMocker)

Title: Dress codes for high-end restaurants may not be as strict as you think they are
